metadata.case_name: Writ Petition No. 266 of 1972 (Detenu v. State of West Bengal)

facts.text: Petitioner was an employee of the Government of West Bengal in the Collectorate of Hooghly District.

Petitioner arrested on January 29, 1972 pursuant to detention order dated January 25, 1972 passed by District Magistrate, Hooghly under s.3(2) read with s.3(1) of Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971 (MISA) to prevent acting prejudicial to maintenance of public order.
Grounds of detention served on petitioner on January 29, 1972 in connection with incidents on April 25, 1971, September 14, 1971, October 12, 1971 and January 19, 1972.
Before detention order, petitioner and six others prosecuted for first two incidents based on FIR dated September 14, 1971 under s.143/506 IPC.
Petitioner and others discharged by Magistrate on March 29, 1972 on police final report dated March 10, 1972.
Petitioner detained in Hooghly jail pursuant to detention order.
Mother of petitioner filed Application No. 318 of 1972 in Calcutta High Court under s.491 CrPC challenging detention on grounds of vagueness and irrelevance of grounds; dismissed on May 29, 1972.
Case referred to Advisory Board under MISA; Board reported sufficient cause for detention.
State Government confirmed detention order on April 15, 1972 under s.12(1) MISA directing detention to continue for three years from date of detention; communicated to detenu.
Petitioner made representation to State Government on August 10, 1972; not considered as writ petition pending before Supreme Court.
All steps under MISA complied with in time and manner prescribed.
District Magistrate filed counter-affidavit denying all grounds of challenge.
Petitioner applied to urge additional grounds on October 24, 1972; liberty granted, petition amended.
Hearing before Constitution Bench on November 17, 1972, November 21, 1972, December 1, 1972; contention on s.17A raised, referred to larger bench.

legal_issues.text: Whether grounds of detention were vague.
Whether nexus between grounds and maintenance of public order.
Whether grounds mechanically framed without detaining authority applying mind.
Whether detention order mala fide and for collateral purpose to victimise members of State Coordination Committee.
Whether s.6(6)(d) and (e) of Defence of India Act, 1971 amending s.13 MISA violates Art.14 by treating citizens and foreigners equally.
Whether confirmation order for three years ultra vires Art.22.
Whether ss.3,5,8,11,12,13 MISA violate Arts.14,19,21,22 for lack of impartial authority to consider representation and challenge materials.
Validity of s.17A MISA introduced by Defence of India Act, allowing detention up to 2 years without Advisory Board opinion in certain cases.
Construction of Art.22(4),(5),(7): whether cl.7 is exception to cl.4, requiring prescription of specific circumstances and classes of cases.

petitioner_arguments.text: No nexus between grounds and maintenance of public order.
Grounds mechanically framed without applying mind.
Order mala fide to victimise State Coordination Committee members.
Amendments by s.6(6)(d),(e) DIA to s.13 MISA violate Art.22(4),(5),(7).
Maximum detention period under amended s.13 and s.17A ultra vires as punitive not preventive.
ss.3,5,8,11,12 MISA unreasonable restrictions violating Arts.14,19,21; no independent body for representation.
s.17A provides unguided discretion; violates Art.22(7) by not prescribing specific classes/circumstances.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art.22(7); precedents: Northern India Caterers, State of MP v Thakur Bharat Singh, etc.

respondent_arguments.text: Denied all grounds of challenge to detention order.
Art.22(4),(7) provide independent powers; cl.7 enabling, 'and' disjunctive; heads in entries suffice as circumstances/classes.

court_reasoning.text: No challenge to procedural compliance under MISA; all steps taken properly.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Record shows compliance; no valid objection on that ground.

court_reasoning.text: Art.22(4) lays down general rule of 3 months detention unless Advisory Board or Parliament under cl.7; cl.7 exception requiring prescription of specific circumstances and classes of cases, not mere enumeration of legislative heads.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Overrules Gopalan majority on construction of Art.22(4),(7); 'and' conjunctive.

court_reasoning.text: s.17A merely repeats heads from entries (defence, security, public order) without prescribing specific circumstances/classes, failing Art.22(7)(a).
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.17A invalid as inconsistent with Art.22(7)(a).

court_reasoning.text: No discrimination under Art.14 from s.10 and s.17A operating together due to non-obstante clause.
Preventive detention necessary evil; Arts.19,21,22 inter-related post-Cooper; but not deciding other challenges as s.17A sufficient.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Need not decide on ss.3,5,8 etc. or Art.14/19/21.

holdings.text: Section 17A of MISA invalid for non-compliance with Art.22(7)(a) as it does not prescribe specific circumstances and classes of cases.
Art.22(4)(a) general rule requiring Advisory Board for detention >3 months; Art.22(7)(a) exception limited to Parliament prescribing both circumstances and classes of cases specifically.

precedents_cited.relevance: Reconsidered majority view on cl.7 as exception requiring specific prescription, not mere heads.

precedents_cited.case_name: Northern India Caterers Private Ltd. v. Punjab
State of M.P. v. Thakur Bharat Singh
G. Nageswara Rao v. State of A.P.
Satwant Singh Sawhney v. D. Ramarathnam
R.C. Cooper v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Arts.19 etc. inter-related; disapproves Gopalan on self-contained code.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bengal Immunity Co. Ltd. v. Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: On reconsidering precedents in constitutional matters.

statutes_cited.name: Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971 (MISA)
statutes_cited.relevance: Detention order under s.3; procedures; s.17A held invalid.

statutes_cited.name: Defence of India Act, 1971
statutes_cited.relevance: Amended MISA s.13 and inserted s.17A during emergency.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Challenges to reasonableness, equality, procedure; Art.22(4),(7) key to s.17A invalidity.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: High Court application; comparison of safeguards.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court declared s.17A of MISA unconstitutional for failing to comply with Art.22(7)(a) by not prescribing specific circumstances and classes of cases for detention without Advisory Board. Did not decide other challenges to detention or provisions as unnecessary.

key_quotes.text: "cl. 4(a) of Art. 22 lays down a rule to which cl. 4(b) read with cl. 7(a) is an exception."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on construction of Art.22 distinguishing ordinary from exceptional detention.

key_quotes.text: "Sec. 17A of the Act, in our opinion, has failed to comply with the requirement of cl. 7(a), and has therefore, to be declared bad as being inconsistent with that clause."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "With great respect to the distinguished judges who formed the majority in Gopalan, we are unable to concur in their views on the construction of cl. 4(b) and cl. 7(a) of Art. 22."
key_quotes.speaker: court
